user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_destroy:
```c
void
MHD_pool_destroy (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  if (NULL == pool)
    return;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
  if (! pool->is_mmap)
    free (pool->memory);
  else
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && ! defined(_WIN32)
    munmap (pool->memory,
            pool->size);
#elif defined(_WIN32)
    VirtualFree (pool->memory,
                 0,
                 MEM_RELEASE);
#else
    abort ();
#endif
  free (pool);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
_MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: pool->memory is a mutable buffer being unpoisoned and then freed, so passing a non‑const pointer to _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY is appropriate. Rule 8.13 requires pointers be const‑qualified when they point to data that will not be modified; in this destroy path the memory is mutable (and likely subject to operations that require a non‑const pointer), so there is no breach. (If, instead, pool->memory were never modified anywhere and _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY only inspected it, then declaring the pointer or the function parameter as pointing to a const-qualified type would be required — that would be a violation in the current code.)
